facts.text: Appeal by special leave from order dated October 5, 1962 of Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated October 5, 1962 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad in Application No. 53 of 1961 in Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 196.1.

facts.text: Application No. 53 of 1961 before Tribunal in Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Dhanbad in Application No. 53 of 1961 in Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 196.1. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd., Jamadoba filed application under s. 33(2)(b) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd.,  N 4SCI Jamadoba, filed an application under s. 33 2  b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  No. 14 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act , before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad  hereinafter called the Tribunal , asking for its approval of the action which it proposed to take against its employee, the respondent D. R. Singh.

facts.text: Application sought approval for action against employee respondent D. R. Singh

anchor.surface_text: before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad  hereinafter called the Tribunal , asking for its approval of the action which it proposed to take against its employee, the respondent D. R. Singh. This application was made by the appellant, because certain industrial disputes were pending at the relevant time between the appellant and its employees under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961.

facts.text: Industrial disputes pending under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961 between appellant and its employees

anchor.surface_text: This application was made by the appellant, because certain industrial disputes were pending at the relevant time between the appellant and its employees under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961. This application was opposed by the respondent who filed his written statement.

facts.text: Respondent D. R. Singh opposed the application and filed written statement

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by the respondent who filed his written statement. At the hearing of the application, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that though it had made the present application as a matter of abundant caution, its case was that it was number necessary to apply under s. 32 2 ,

facts.text: Appellant contended that s.33(2) not applicable as respondent not concerned with pending industrial disputes

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the application, the appellant urged before the Tribunal that though it had made the present application as a matter of abundant caution, its case was that it was number necessary to apply under s. 32 2 , because the respondent was number companycerned with the industrial disputes which were pending between the appellant and its employees in the different References to which we have already referred.

facts.text: Tribunal held appellant could not raise contention that s.33 not applicable

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal took the view that the appellant companyld number raise such a companytention. It held that if the appellant thought that s. 33 did number apply, it should withdraw the application and take the companysequences. On that view, it refused to entertain the plea raised by the appellant and proceeded to deal with the merits of the application.

facts.text: Tribunal not satisfied prima facie case for dismissal of respondent, refused approval, dismissed application

anchor.surface_text: and proceeded to deal with the merits of the application. In the result, the Tribunal was number satisfied that a prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent, and so, approval was number accorded to the action which the appellant wanted to take against the respondent and its application was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave against Tribunal's order

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave. The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant companytends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in number dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case.

facts.text: Order terminating services of respondent passed on December 4, 1961 effective from December 9, 1961

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, however, we do number propose to adopt such a companyrse. The order terminating the services of the respondent was passed on December 4, 1961 and it was to take effect from December 9, 1961. The Award was pronounced by the Tribunal on October 5, 1962,

facts.text: Tribunal pronounced award on October 5, 1962

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating the services of the respondent was passed on December 4, 1961 and it was to take effect from December 9, 1961. The Award was pronounced by the Tribunal on October 5, 1962, and when the appeal has companye for final disposal before us, more than three years have elapsed since the date of dismissal of the respondent.

facts.text: More than three years elapsed since dismissal of respondent by time of Supreme Court hearing

anchor.surface_text: The Award was pronounced by the Tribunal on October 5, 1962, and when the appeal has companye for final disposal before us, more than three years have elapsed since the date of dismissal of the respondent. The learned Solicitor-General fairly company- ceded that the appellant has companye to this Court number so much to enforce its order of dismissal against the respondent,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal erred in not considering preliminary point on applicability of s.33

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General for the appellant companytends, and we think rightly, that the Tribunal was in error in number dealing with the preliminary point as to whether s. 33 applied to the facts of this case. It is plain that in a situation like the present, even if the appellant took the view that the workman against whom it was taking action was number a workman companycerned with the main industrial disputes,

facts.text: Appellant made application under s.33 as precautionary measure

anchor.surface_text: In order to avoid any companyplica- tions and with a view to save itself from the charge that it had companytravened s. 33 of the Act, the appellant had numberdoubt made an application as a precautionary measure that is why it wanted the Tribunal to companysider its companytention that s. 33 did number apply as a preliminary point.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal without examining merits due to long passage of time

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we have decided that point in favour of the appellant, but having regard to the long passage of time between the date of the impugned order and the date when we are pronouncing our judgment in the present appeal, we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal with a direction that it should decide the preliminary point raised by the appellant as to whether the respondent is a workman companycerned in such disputes within the meaning of s. 33 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent not a workman concerned in disputes was preliminary contention accepted by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the Tribunal was in error in number companysidering the preliminary point raised by the appellant that the respondent was number a workman companycerned with the main industrial disputes and as such, the application made by it was unnecessary. That raises the question as to the companyrse that we should adopt in dealing with the merits of the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: consider the question as to whether the respondent was a workman concerned in the relevant industrial disputes at all, before dealing with the merits of its application. holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in not considering the preliminary point raised by the appellant that the respondent was not a workman concerned with the main industrial disputes and as such, the application made by it was unnecessary

holdings.text: This Court has approved of the broader construction of the words workmen concerned in such dispute

anchor.surface_text: This problem was ultimately resolved by this Court in its two recent decisions, viz., New India Motors Private Ltd. v. Morris K.T. and Digwadih Colliery v. Ramji Singh. In this latter case this Court considered the conflicting judicial decisions rendered by the different High Courts and has approved of the broader construction of the words workmen concerned in such dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolves High Court conflicts by endorsing Digwadih Colliery's broader interpretation over narrow views
